e4: Adopting the new policy promotes transparency and integrity in financial reporting, aligning with ethical business practices. While transitioning may initially confuse some investors, strategic communication and education can mitigate misunderstandings. Ultimately, this change reduces legal risks and builds long-term investor trust by demonstrating a commitment to honesty and accuracy.
e5: An ethical reporting policy ensures transparency, accuracy, and fairness. It adheres to legal standards and provides all stakeholders with a true reflection of the company's financial health without bias or manipulation. Such a policy considers the potential impact on all investors, especially less sophisticated ones, and seeks to prevent any advantage of information asymmetry. Additionally, it involves clear communication regarding any changes to reporting practices to maintain trust and understanding among all market participants.
e6: How will the management ensure effective communication about the new policy to all investors, especially retail? What measures are in place to monitor the market's reaction and investor understanding post-policy change? How does management plan to handle any potential short-term negative impacts on stock performance due to misunderstanding of the new policy?
